questions.questionText: A forecaster uses past inflation and interest rates to predict next quarter’s inflation and tunes the model to minimize out-of-sample error. What is the primary goal?
A survey samples different households in 2018 and a new independent sample in 2024 (no tracking of the same households). What type of data is this?
In the OLS model y = b0 + b1 x + u, which sample property holds by the first-order conditions?
options: Residuals sum to the mean of $y$

questions.questionText: A simple regression of CEO salary on profits yields R^2 = 0.09. Correct interpretation?
options: 9% of the variation in salary is explained by profits
questions.correctAnswer: 9% of the variation in salary is explained by profits

questions.questionText: Log–log model: log(Sales) = 3.8 + 0.45 log(AdSpend). Interpretation of 0.45?
options: €1 more AdSpend raises sales by 0.45 units
1% more AdSpend is associated with 0.45% more sales
1% more AdSpend raises sales by 0.45 units
Elasticity of log-sales w.r.t. AdSpend in euros
questions.correctAnswer: 1% more AdSpend is associated with 0.45% more sales

questions.questionText: Log–level model: log(y) = a + b x with b = 0.08. Best interpretation?
options: A one-unit increase in $x$ changes $y$ by 0.08 units
A one-unit increase in $x$ is associated with an 8% increase in $y$
A one-unit increase in $x$ is associated with a 0.08% increase in $y$
questions.correctAnswer: A one-unit increase in x is associated with an 8% increase in y

questions.questionText: Wage on Education omits Ability. Ability is positively correlated with Education and positively affects Wage. Direction of bias on Education?
Which is a bad control when estimating the effect of education on wages?
options: Current occupation if partly determined by education (mediator)
questions.correctAnswer: Current occupation if partly determined by education (mediator)

questions.questionText: Which change generally makes the OLS slope more precise?
In y = b0 + b1 x1 + b2 x2 + u, b1 measures:
questions.correctAnswer: Effect of x1 on y holding x2 constant

questions.questionText: To test that several coefficients are jointly zero, use:
High (not perfect) multicollinearity primarily causes:
Dummy/interactions model: Wage = b0 + b1 Female + b2 Educ + b3(Female×Educ) + u. What does b3 measure?
options: Difference in returns to education between females and males
questions.correctAnswer: Difference in returns to education between females and males

questions.questionText: Adjusted R^2 compared to R^2:
options: Penalizes extra regressors and can fall when adding irrelevant variables
questions.correctAnswer: Penalizes extra regressors and can fall when adding irrelevant variables

questions.questionText: AIC vs BIC: typically, BIC:
options: Penalizes less and selects larger models
Penalizes more and selects simpler models
questions.correctAnswer: Penalizes more and selects simpler models

questions.questionText: A time series is covariance stationary if:
options: Mean, variance, and autocovariance are time-invariant
It has a deterministic trend only
questions.correctAnswer: Mean, variance, and autocovariance are time-invariant

questions.questionText: ADF test is primarily used to:
Regressing two unrelated trending series on each other with high R^2 indicates:
In AR(1): Y_t = a + r Y_{t-1} + u_t, |r|=1 implies:
White noise errors u_t are characterized by:
options: Zero mean, constant variance, no autocorrelation
questions.correctAnswer: Zero mean, constant variance, no autocorrelation

questions.questionText: A correlogram (ACF plot) shows bars outside confidence bands at low lags. This suggests:
options: Statistically significant autocorrelation at those lags
questions.correctAnswer: Statistically significant autocorrelation at those lags

questions.questionText: Breusch–Godfrey test is used to detect:
options: Serial correlation up to order p in residuals
questions.correctAnswer: Serial correlation up to order p in residuals

questions.questionText: In an MA(q) model, for horizon h > q, forecasts tend to:
options: Oscillate randomly around zero with growing variance

questions.questionText: In an ARDL(p,q) model, the long-run multiplier for X represents:
options: Immediate impact of X on Y
Total equilibrium change in Y after a permanent change in X
Persistence of Y via AR terms
questions.correctAnswer: Total equilibrium change in Y after a permanent change in X

questions.questionText: Comparing two forecasting models using RMSE, a lower RMSE indicates:
Including a linear time trend t in a regression primarily captures:
Fixed Effects (Within) estimator removes unobserved time-invariant heterogeneity by:
Which coefficient cannot be identified in a standard Fixed Effects model?
options: A time-invariant characteristic (e.g., gender) for an individual
questions.correctAnswer: A time-invariant characteristic (e.g., gender) for an individual

questions.questionText: Strict exogeneity in panels requires that regressors are uncorrelated with:
options: All past, current, and future idiosyncratic errors
questions.correctAnswer: All past, current, and future idiosyncratic errors

questions.questionText: FE vs First Differences: FD is preferred over FE when idiosyncratic errors:
A balanced panel means:
options: All individuals observed for all time periods
Equal numbers of individuals and periods
Identical values of regressors across time
questions.correctAnswer: All individuals observed for all time periods

questions.questionText: Within vs Between variation: Fixed Effects estimates rely primarily on:
Which statement best distinguishes prediction from causal inference in econometrics?
options: Prediction requires randomized experiments; causation does not
Prediction optimizes forecast accuracy; causal inference seeks unbiased effect estimates
Causal inference ignores identification; prediction focuses on it
questions.correctAnswer: Prediction optimizes forecast accuracy; causal inference seeks unbiased effect estimates

questions.questionText: Which dataset is time series data?
options: Graduates surveyed in 2018 and a new sample in 2024

questions.questionText: In simple OLS, which is guaranteed by the normal equations?
options: Residuals are independent and identically distributed

questions.questionText: Level–log model: y = a + b log(x). If b = 2.5, a 1% increase in x is associated with:
Omitted variable bias: X (education) is negatively correlated with the omitted variable Z (local unemployment risk), and Z positively affects Y (wages). Direction of bias on education?
Which is a symptom of high (but not perfect) multicollinearity?
options: Large standard errors and unstable coefficient signs across similar specifications
questions.correctAnswer: Large standard errors and unstable coefficient signs across similar specifications

questions.questionText: In a model with k restrictions tested jointly, which statement is correct?
options: For k=1, the F-test equals the squared t-test
For any k, the F-test equals the squared t-test
The F-test cannot be used when k=1
The t-test is always more powerful than the F-test
questions.correctAnswer: For k=1, the F-test equals the squared t-test

questions.questionText: Categorical variable with 5 groups. How many dummies do you include to avoid the dummy variable trap (with an intercept)?
In Wage = b0 + b1 Female + b2 Educ + b3(Female×Educ) + u, what is the return to education for females?
AIC/BIC are used primarily to:
options: Balance fit and complexity for model selection
questions.correctAnswer: Balance fit and complexity for model selection

questions.questionText: Random walk property: for X_t = X_{t-1} + u_t with Var(u_t)=σ², what is Var(X_t) (starting at X_0=0)?
ACF patterns: which statement is most typical?
options: AR(1) ACF cuts off after lag 1; MA(1) ACF decays geometrically
AR(1) ACF decays geometrically; MA(1) ACF cuts off after lag 1
Both AR(1) and MA(1) ACF cut off after lag 1
Both AR(1) and MA(1) ACF decay geometrically
questions.correctAnswer: AR(1) ACF decays geometrically; MA(1) ACF cuts off after lag 1

questions.questionText: ADF test on a series including a constant yields p-value = 0.03. Using 5% significance, conclude:
options: Fail to reject unit root; series is non-stationary
Reject unit root; series is stationary around a constant
questions.correctAnswer: Reject unit root; series is stationary around a constant

questions.questionText: BG test auxiliary regression includes:
options: Only the dependent variable and its lag

questions.questionText: AR(1): y_t = c + φ y_{t-1} + u_t with |φ|<1. The long-run (unconditional) mean of y_t equals:
Forecast evaluation: MAPE can be problematic when:
options: Actual values are close to zero
questions.correctAnswer: Actual values are close to zero

questions.questionText: ARDL intuition: the long-run multiplier divides the sum of X-lag coefficients by:
A model’s residual correlogram shows no significant autocorrelation at any lag. This suggests the model is:
First Differences (FD) vs Fixed Effects (FE): when T=2, which is true?
options: FD and FE are numerically identical for slope coefficients
questions.correctAnswer: FD and FE are numerically identical for slope coefficients

questions.questionText: Including individual and time dummies in a panel regression primarily controls for:
options: Time-invariant individual heterogeneity and common shocks over time
questions.correctAnswer: Time-invariant individual heterogeneity and common shocks over time

questions.questionText: Strict exogeneity fails in FE when the model includes:
Unbalanced panels: which statement is correct?
options: FE cannot be estimated with unbalanced panels
FE can be estimated; observations with missing years are dropped where needed
Only FD works with unbalanced panels
questions.correctAnswer: FE can be estimated; observations with missing years are dropped where needed

questions.questionText: If residuals in a time-series regression show heteroskedasticity and autocorrelation, a common remedy for inference is to use:
Distributed lag model with β0=0.4 and β1=0.3 (X_t and X_{t-1} only). The long-run (total) multiplier equals:
ARMA(1,1) one- vs two-step forecasts: which statement is most accurate?
options: At $h=2$, the MA component still enters via future shocks
At $h=2$, the MA component drops out because future shocks have zero conditional mean
At $h=1$, only the MA component matters
ARMA forecasts revert immediately to the mean at $h=1$
questions.correctAnswer: At h=2, the MA component drops out because future shocks have zero conditional mean
